Posts.Content: Am wondering what your definition of "survivor" is.  Daughter was diagnosed in June 2015 with Stage IV BC.  She had to discontinue Ibrance due to such low WBC.  Now she's on Afinitor and Aromasin which is driving her glucose extremely high.  Her latest PET scan shows the cancer has not spread any further.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer stage 4 survivors

Posts.Content: My daughter was on Ibrance and Letrazole for about six months.  She had to discontinue the Ibrance but continued the Letrazole until her Afinitor and Aromasin arrived.  She never experienced any hair loss while on Letrazole.
Posts.Title: Hair Loss using Letrozole

Posts.Content: Self exam is so important.  My daughter had a "clear" mammogram in December of 2015.  In June 2016 she found a baseball-size lump that turned out to be Stage IV BC.  She has very dense breasts.  Who knows if she had had an ultra sound instead of a mammo, they may have discovered the cancer before it spread to her bones and liver?
Posts.Title: Mammogram question

Posts.Content: Were you taking anything with the Letrazole?  My daughter's been on Letrazole for nearly a year now.  She was been taking it with Ibrance until her WBC went too low. She's been on Letrazole alone now for several months waiting for prescriptions for Aromasin and Afinitor to be filled.  She hasn't lost hair that I know of but I'm on this message board because she will not talk about her health to me.
Posts.Title: Hair Loss using Letrozole

Posts.Content: Candy, don't be ashamed to see a therapist, if you don't have someone with whom you can discuss your feelings.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed

Posts.Content: OMG, Candy.  My daughter, 60 y.o. was diagnosed in June 2016 with Stage IV BC.  Her first bone scan showed the cancer had spread to her liver and bones and she was going to keep it a secret from me.  I found out by mistake in October 2015.  I'm the basket case.  She acts as though there's nothing wrong.  I'm so baffled by her.  I go to her doctor's appointments with her but she acts as though she resents me asking questions.  I have so many questions but don't want to cause a fracture in mine and my daughter's relationship.  She is divorced with no children and my husband died of cancer 10 years ago.  I'm terrified. Correction.  I found out in October 2016.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed

Posts.Content: Candy, don't be ashamed to see a therapist, if you don't have someone with whom you can discuss your feelings.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed

Posts.Content: I have a Power of Attorney and that's how I'm able to go to the imaging company and get her reports before we see the doctor.  My daughter is not interested in seeing them or knowing what's of interest in them.  These reports are never published on the patient's portal so the patient never sees them unless they request a copy. You have my interest peeked now about why they claim the mass will never be removed.  I know 20-30 years ago you would hear that doctor's didn't want to "disturb" the tumor for fear of spreading the cancer.  But, I believe we've come a long way since then.  Had I been with her at this last visit I would have asked if they plan to do an MRI since the report said the only way they could determine the size of the mass was with an MRI.  I asked my daughter if an MRI was mentioned and she said no.  But she had no idea why I was asking.  I don't want her to get to the point where she doesn't have confidence in her doctor by my asking so many questions.  It's like being between a rock and a hard place.
Posts.Title: Calling all alternative cancer treatments experiences...

Posts.Content: Your math is right on and I have a mind of my own.  I'm a digger.  Google on my computer is nearly worn out.  I want to know everything and that's the rub between my daughter and myself.  She has no curiosity about her "condition."
Posts.Title: Calling all alternative cancer treatments experiences...

Posts.Title: Calling all alternative cancer treatments experiences...

Posts.Content: On Jul 17, 2014 11:03 PM SpringFlowers wrote: Dx 2010/BC already Stg4 -due to misread mammogram. I have NEVER had chemo, no radiaition.  I opted for Laser Surgery, kept my breast, removed the tumor.  No pain, no long recuperation, no need for reconstruction and all the misery. Got off op table, went to dinner that evening, returned home in two days.  My tumor was 9cm, had soft tissue tumors everywhere, lungs, liver, Did the Asparagus cure, laughed at myself, but in 90 days, they were gone, but I think the Laser rid most of the invasion.  Google MinaBissel/TEDconference, explains how the body works to rid cancer cells, I try to stay on a ph neg diet, cancer cannot live in an oxygenated enviornment, cells cannot reproduce.  My tumor markers are now normal, I am no fan of chemo, the bodyis already compromised, chemo only rapidly diminishes healthy cells.  Get your immune system in top order, yes, Reishi/Mitake/Shitake do help, also Fucoidan or Ufn, Curcumin, Inositol 6, Indole 3/Carbinol, Beta Glucan.  Do your homework, you can beat the beast, i'm nearing end of 5 years, onco's said i'd never live to see 2012, but i'm still here.  He's miffied, who cares?   Laser can light up areas of invasion of cancer and eradicate.  Docs/Onco's hate laser due to it being so easy, not to mention cheap.  Cancer can bring in anywhere from 1 -2 million, cancer is the gift that keeps on giving, why do you think they build all these cancer centers??  None are better than the ones already here, they all follow the exact protocol.  Surgery, Radiaion, Chemo, Reconstuction, More chemo, it's a merry go round.  Thankful I refused the ride before I ever got on.  Best to you, I know it's not easy.  ck:LaserBreastCancerSurgery.com.   You deserve to be more than a bank deposit slip. This is all so confusing to me.  As I read your post, you already had Stage IV BC and your tumor was removed.  My daughter was first diagnosed in June 2016 with Stage IV BC with mets to bones and liver.  I asked when would they remove the tumor and the doctor said "probably never; we won't put her under unnecessary surgery."  Her tumor size originally was 8 cm but her latest scan says the tumor has shrunk to 6 cm.  I just don't understand why some tumors are removed even though the cancer has spread and some tumors are not removed.
Posts.Title: Calling all alternative cancer treatments experiences...

Posts.Content: Thank you so much for your non-sugar-coated answer.  Since this is my daughter's body and her cancer I feel like my hands are tied in trying to get a second opinion.  All her blood work comes back good except for her diabetes.  She's 60 years old, which seems young to me.  The more I read the more confused I become.   However, after receiving a blisteringresponse to a question I asked not long ago, I'm very careful what I write/question on the site.
Posts.Title: Calling all alternative cancer treatments experiences...

Posts.Content: Again, thank you for your civil comments.  I call ahead and get the results of my daughter's scans, etc. because I want to know if I should have questions.  Since she seems to resent my asking questions, I decided maybe I should not go to her doctor's appointments with her.  She had an appointment last Friday and I intentionally scheduled another appointment for myself.  She came over to my house later that day and questioned why I would schedule something else, knowing she had a doctor's appointment that day.  I figured it was finally time for me to let her know that I feel her appointments are more stressful when I'm there.  Anyway, some of the air was cleared and she did actually say she wants me to come to her doctor's appointments with her. She is divorced and has no children -- therefore no support group.  I don't know if you read this or not but her latest ultra sound indicates the tumor is 6 cm but the person writing the report said they could not get an exact measurement without doing an MRI.  Of course my daughter doesn't know what the report said because she hasn't  seen it.  I asked how her appointment went and was there any discussion about her having an MRI.  Answer: no.  Have I mentioned she hardly ever sees the doctor.  A PA talks with her and writes notes.  I once asked if there's a protocol as to how often the patient sees the doctor and the answer was "if the patient is stable, they don't see the doctor."  That didn't make me feel very happy.
Posts.Title: Calling all alternative cancer treatments experiences...

Posts.Content: Can anyone tell me if these are one in the same? Dr. talks about shrinking the tumor then doing "chemo."  All the drugs my daughter is taking are labeled "chemo drugs."  What's the difference in chemo in pill form and chemo intravenously?
Posts.Title: Shrinking the tumor; stopping the spread
